text: It’s also possible that neither Pappert wasn’t wrong, nor is Hermans very wrong, just that her ways of teaching work better in the Dutch culture where she tried them, and that differences between cultures sometimes matter.

elements.text: It’s also possible that neither Pappert wasn’t wrong, nor is Hermans very wrong, just that her ways of teaching work better in the Dutch culture where she tried them, and that differences between cultures sometimes matter.

text: Just changing some of the infrastructure to make clients/browsers more heavyweight ought to make them quite a bit more responsive. I guess that’s pretty much Electron & co? But companies like Slack appear to put only minimal logic in the thick client, and prefer to fetch data over caching it, for freshness and better consistency.

elements.text: Just changing some of the infrastructure to make clients/browsers more heavyweight ought to make them quite a bit more responsive. I guess that’s pretty much Electron & co? But companies like Slack appear to put only minimal logic in the thick client, and prefer to fetch data over caching it, for freshness and better consistency.

text: I'd say distributed includes decentralized. 'App' is probably not a great word - I just mean interactive processes that span the network. Includes manipulating and sharing media objects, playing games, etc.

elements.text: I'd say distributed includes decentralized. 'App' is probably not a great word - I just mean interactive processes that span the network. Includes manipulating and sharing media objects, playing games, etc.

text: No, decentralized implies distributed.

elements.text: No, decentralized implies distributed.

text: Yes, that too.

text: Right, so that vision is a lot more compelling to me, but it involves a radical change of ownership. It’s a lot harder to make money, and you need a lot more social coordination to decide on shared representations of things.

elements.text: Right, so that vision is a lot more compelling to me, but it involves a radical change of ownership. It’s a lot harder to make money, and you need a lot more social coordination to decide on shared representations of things.

text: You can imagine it working a lot of different ways. Which variations are achievable is hard to know.

elements.text: You can imagine it working a lot of different ways. Which variations are achievable is hard to know.

text: Technically, I think you need bits of immutable data, mostly representing changes to things, and a way of partially ordering them. *RDTs, approximately. Some shared notion (or notions) of identity, way(s) of proving authenticity.

elements.text: Technically, I think you need bits of immutable data, mostly representing changes to things, and a way of partially ordering them. *RDTs, approximately. Some shared notion (or notions) of identity, way(s) of proving authenticity.

text: Is it harder to make money? I think the economic models may be different but commercial activity would still exist.

elements.text: Is it harder to make money? I think the economic models may be different but commercial activity would still exist.

text: I assume you've seen the work coming out of Ink and Switch? They had a good write up about Local First.

text: Yeah, and Peter and I chatted last year. I think we’re aligned at a high level on the fundamentals.

elements.text: Yeah, and Peter and I chatted last year. I think we’re aligned at a high level on the fundamentals.

text: I guess I don’t really know about making money. Just that a number of companies only exist now because of the effort involved in making something that does anything, making it available and reliable, etc.

text: You can turn the question around a bit and ask, what’s needed to do the things we actually want to do online? Where are collective ownership of ~apps, or private ownership of data, most important to us?

elements.text: You can turn the question around a bit and ask, what’s needed to do the things we actually want to do online? Where are collective ownership of ~apps, or private ownership of data, most important to us?

text: I think of this model as a virtual distributed world where we have private ownership of objects. We still need infra to provide the shared spaces, messaging etc.

elements.text: I think of this model as a virtual distributed world where we have private ownership of objects. We still need infra to provide the shared spaces, messaging etc.

text: We'd still buy, share tools to manipulate our objects. Maybe pay for shared spaces to bring them into, etc.

elements.text: We'd still buy, share tools to manipulate our objects. Maybe pay for shared spaces to bring them into, etc.

text: I don't think of this as collective ownership.

elements.text: I don't think of this as collective ownership.

text: The main feature would be your media wouldn't be locked in by services that control the access and also provide the manipulation tools.

elements.text: The main feature would be your media wouldn't be locked in by services that control the access and also provide the manipulation tools.

text: I don't know if this makes sense. Need a bit more work to phrase it better.

text: <https://twitter.com/chatur_shalabh/status/1187370714204127232>

attachments.fallback: <https://twitter.com/chatur_shalabh|@chatur_shalabh>: <https://twitter.com/yoshikischmitz|@yoshikischmitz> <https://twitter.com/geoffreylitt|@geoffreylitt> You live in a persistent virtual world. You have data objects. You have functions that project views of these objects. Other functions transform the objects. You pick up functions that whack them on objects whenever you want (no blanket permissions).
attachments.text: <https://twitter.com/yoshikischmitz|@yoshikischmitz> <https://twitter.com/geoffreylitt|@geoffreylitt> You live in a persistent virtual world. You have data objects. You have functions that project views of these objects. Other functions transform the objects. You pick up functions that whack them on objects whenever you want (no blanket permissions).

text: I subscribe to the broader decentralized vision you are talking about though. I think standardizing on data formats is one way to do it. You could also standardize on mobile objects, for instance..maybe?

elements.text: I subscribe to the broader decentralized vision you are talking about though. I think standardizing on data formats is one way to do it. You could also standardize on mobile objects, for instance..maybe?

text: Re: infra, yes. That infrastructure becomes a commodity, which is probably a good thing. The IPFS/etc people are trying to see how much of that infrastructure can be commoditized, decentralized, and distributed globally. I’m glad they’re exploring it, and hope they have enough success that they start to find the limits of the approach.

elements.text: Re: infra, yes. That infrastructure becomes a commodity, which is probably a good thing. The IPFS/etc people are trying to see how much of that infrastructure can be commoditized, decentralized, and distributed globally. I’m glad they’re exploring it, and hope they have enough success that they start to find the limits of the approach.
